I don't drink, but I see nothing particularly wrong with drinking in moderation. The reason a lot of Churches have been against alcohol is linked to the rise of the non-conformist movements in Britain. At the time gin was cheap and abundant, it was causing the poor to drown their sorrows and leave their families destitute. The non-conformist movement talked about "the demon drink" in the context of the effect it had on society and on families. Alcoholism is best combatted by teetotalism, and this is what the non-conformist churches advocated. The methodists I know have no relaxed their prohibitions on alcohol, though they still use grape juice for communion as many methodists are still teetotal.

 First, you're opening statement isn't even true--most churches don't oppose drinking. Fundamentalist churches, especially in the U.S. "Bible belt" often do. That's not most churches by far.
 
 More churches worldwide even use alcoholic wine in communion than those that do not.
 
 Second, I don't think we need to assume that there weren't Palestinian 1st century equivilent of bars back then. There's no record of Jesus ever visiting such a place, so I don't think He would have spent much time at Hooters at all.
 
 Because of the negativity associated with drinking in the prohibition years, to this day people here in the U.S. associate drinking mainly with wild partying or lwed behavior. But overseas in many countries, they are wine-cultures, and drinking is an everyday way of life. There's no stigma to it. I think that is more the way it probably was in Jesus' culture. I wish the U.S. was more that way.
